subject: Test with no @Test inside, was Re: Test with no class inside
msgSnippet: Hi Joe, I wonder what you mean by Marking the super-test-class abstract in your reply. Is my superclass (FirstTest) not already abstract ? Regards, Al ...
messageBody:
Hi Joe,

I wonder what you mean by "Marking the super-test-class abstract" in
your reply. Is my superclass (FirstTest) not already abstract ?

Regards,

Al

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...> wrote:
>
> Al May wrote:
> >
> >
> > Hi,
> >
> > Is it possible to have a test class without any tests inside its body
> > (e.g. with no @Test annotation inside) ? It's because I've created an
> > abstract class containing all my tests and I extend this class for
> > each implementation that I have to test. By doing this, I don't need
> > to write redundant code to test different kind of implementations. To
> > help you better understand, I give you an example :
> >
> > public abstract class FirstTest {
> >
> > @Test
> > public test1() {
> > // ...
> > IFactory factory = getFactory();
> > // ...
> > }
> >
> > @Test
> > public test2() {
> > // ...
> > IFactory factory = getFactory();
> > // ...
> > }
> >
> > protected abstract IFactory getFactory();
> >
> > }
> >
> > /*
> > * This class should be considered a test class even there is no
> > * @Test inside. Normally, it inherit all the test methods from
> > * the superclass.
> > *
> > */
> > public class Implementation1Test extends FirstTest {
> >
> > protected IFactory getFactory() {
> > return new MyFirstImplementationFactory();
> > }
> >
> > }
> >
> > Now, if I try to run Implementation1Test as a JUnit test, Eclipse
> > reports me an error. I have to specify at least one @Test annotation
> > in my concrete test class. Is there anybody who can help how to do
that ?
>
> I believe this is a known Eclipse problem, so I recommend asking
Eclipse
> people, rather than JUnit people. I had the same problem with Eclipse
> running JUnit 3 tests. Marking the super-test-class abstract worked
> around the problem there.
